body: So you are mapping the same entity to both a table AND a view ???

> So you are mapping the same entity to both a table AND a view ???

Yes - according to the documentation, this should use the view for reading, and the table for updating. It's useful when you soft-delete data, and you have a view such as `CREATE VIEW ActiveObjects AS SELECT * FROM Objects WHERE Deleted = 0` - I want to always read from the view so that I don't read deleted data, but updating the view can cause issues (update the Deleted flag from 0 to 1 is particularly interesting...)

Although the current behaviour is not as described in the documentation, it would be interesting to discuss what the expected behaviour really ought to be. At the very least, I feel the documentation should be updated to reflect the actual behaviour - although I’m undecided on whether the current behaviour is what I’d want.

If a row is excluded in the view, and ExecuteUpdate updated the table without reference to the view, would ExecuteUpdate be updating more rows than expected? Perhaps it is better to update the view in this case... but this won't work with some providers (e.g. SqLite)? Perhaps there should be a join between the table and the view, so that the table can be updated but only for rows that appear in the view?
@ddashwood You are right, but this would require a fairly big change to fix, so we might need to wait till EF 10
That’s understand Andriy. Any chance of getting the documentation amended in the mean time?
Generally, we don't mention known bugs in the documentation unless they affect the majority of our users, and this scenario seems to be uncommon.

rename.from: ExecuteUpdate updates the view, not the table
rename.to: ExecuteUpdate/Delete attempt to update the view, not the table

issue.title: Handle view mapping in ExecuteDelete/Update translation

repository.name: efcore
repository.description: EF Core is a modern object-database mapper for .NET. It supports LINQ queries, change tracking, updates, and schema migrations.

issue.body:
ExecuteDelete/Update take as input the SelectExpression that was translated so far, just prior to their appearance; that SelectExpression is assumed to be reading the tables, so references views rather than tables.

Note that the query may reference multiples tables. The additional tables (not the one being mutated) do need to be views, as we're reading from them. But during translation, we don't know which table is being updated - the user can start from one root, and project out a navigation to be deleted. So we only know the target table at the end of translation.

So the approach here is to detect the case where the table to be changed is a view, find the table corresponding to that view, and replace it in the SelectExpression.

Note that handling ExecuteUpdate where the property to set is a complex type and there's a vide mapping isn't yet supported; this is blocking on #34706.

Closes #34677

issue.title: Support ExecuteUpdate/Delete with view mapping where the column name differs between the table and view

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Issues that have been approved but are not scheduled a specific release.

repository.name: efcore
repository.description: EF Core is a modern object-database mapper for .NET. It supports LINQ queries, change tracking, updates, and schema migrations.

issue.body:
When ExecuteUpdate/Delete is executed on a table that has a view mapping, special rewriting of the query expression must be done, as the translation references the view but we need to update the table instead (see #34677). This was done in #34709, but without handling the case where column names actually differ between the two mapings:

```c#
modelBuilder.Entity<Cat>()
    .ToTable("Cat", b => b.Property(c => c.Name).HasColumnName("Name"))
    .ToView("CatView", b => b.Property(c => c.Name).HasColumnName("ViewName"));
```

To support this, we need to re-visit the expression, rewriting ColumnExpressions.

issue.title: ExecuteDelete does not respect table mapping when also mapped to a view

repository.name: efcore
repository.description: EF Core is a modern object-database mapper for .NET. It supports LINQ queries, change tracking, updates, and schema migrations.

issue.body:
Since EF5 it has been possible to map to both a view and a table:
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-au/ef/core/modeling/entity-types?tabs=data-annotations#view-mapping

To quote the docs:
_In this case the query mapping will be used for queries and the table mapping will be used for updates._

This works as expected with add, update, delete and select on entities that aren't executed directly. E.g. this works:

```C#
    _context.Approvals.RemoveRange(context.Set<Approval>().Where(x => x.ProjectId == ProjectId).ToList());
    context.SaveChanges();
```

It does NOT work with ExecuteDelete which tries to execute delete on the view instead of the table giving the following exception

```C#
  await _context.Set<Approval>().Where(x => x.ProjectId == ProjectId).ExecuteDelete();
```

Microsoft.Data.SqlException: View or function 'a' is not updatable because the modification affects multiple base tables - which is the error you get if you map just to the view instead of the table.

Is there a workaround until it is fixed?

Related to https://github.com/dotnet/efcore/issues/34694

EF Core version: 7
Database provider: Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore.SqlServer
Target framework: (e.g. .NET 7.0)
Operating system: win 64
IDE: e.g. Visual Studio 2022 17.4
